title: 111_s1930
content: The Act is titled the "Homebuyer Tax Credit Oversight and Accountability Act of 2009" and includes provisions to enhance the administration of the first-time homebuyer tax credit. The "Homebuyer Tax Credit Oversight and Accountability Act of 2009" amends the age limitation for the tax credit, stating that taxpayers must be at least 18 years old at the time of purchasing a residence to qualify for the credit. The "Homebuyer Tax Credit Oversight and Accountability Act of 2009" updates documentation requirements for the tax credit, including the need for a settlement statement and a certified statement of eligibility from the real estate reporting person. The "Homebuyer Tax Credit Oversight and Accountability Act of 2009" updates documentation requirements for the tax credit, including restrictions on married individuals acquiring residence from the family of their spouse and treating certain errors related to the first-time homebuyer tax credit as mathematical or clerical errors. The "Homebuyer Tax Credit Oversight and Accountability Act of 2009" updates documentation requirements for the tax credit, including restrictions on eligibility based on age, inconsistent income tax return information, and failure to attach required forms to the return. The amendments made by this section apply to purchases after the date of the enactment of this Act. The Commissioner of Internal Revenue will investigate and prosecute fraud related to the first-time homebuyer tax credit. Reports on the status of these actions will be provided to Congress within 90 days of the Act's enactment and quarterly thereafter. SEC. 3. Certain tax return preparers required to file returns electronically. SEC. 3 amends subsection (e) of section 6011 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to require individual income tax returns prepared by specified tax return preparers to be filed on magnetic media. The amendment requires tax return preparers who expect to file more than 100 individual income tax returns to file them on magnetic media. The effective date for this change is after December 31, 2010.
